title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 04
author: Various
snippet: The dame was given out as a Duckpool; and itmust have been fairly admitted, even by the proud Bogends, that shecould not have acted her part better though she had been in realitydescended from that house, so favoured by the fifth James, at the verytime that he brought Drumelzier to his knees at Glenwhappen.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 04
author: Various
snippet: "Cauldshouthers is a name as familiar to me as Oliver Castle, orDrochel, or Neidpath, or Drumelzier."

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 04
author: Various
snippet: "So we maun, Grizel; but you've forgot the best part o' the story, howthe Thane o' Drumelzier having heard that a stranger had passed throughhis lands without paying him homage, rode with his men, mounted on whitehorses, after the rebels, and cam up with them just as the king wascarousing after his journey.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 04
author: Various
snippet: "They count as far backas the fifth James, who, passing through Tweeddale, was determined topay nae court to the Thane of Drumelzier; and yet he couldna mak hisway--in a country where hill rides upon hill, and moss joins moss, fraeTweedscross to the Cauldstane-slap--without some assistance, the mair bynote that he stuck in the mire, and might have been there yet, had it nobeen for Jock Bertram, a hind, who got the royal traveller and his menout, and led them through the thane's lands, to Glenwhappen.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 04
author: Various
snippet: True, there was in that county, properly only one thane, viz.,he of Drumelzier, whose castle, now in ruins, may still be seen nearPowsail; but of the lesser order there were many; and, if anygutter-blooded burgher of Linton had, in his cups at Cantswalls, allegedanything to the contrary, he might have been set down as a leveller.
